Award.AwardTitle: Plant perception of insect herbivores includes leaf vibrations caused by chewing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants are attacked by many kinds of insect pests, and quick detection is key to successful defense. A newly discovered way that plants can detect insect attack - sensing vibrations caused by insect chewing - is likely to be faster and more reliable than other known detection systems. This project has four goals. First, the new detection system will be studied in several kinds of plants and insect pests. Second, rapid screening methods for its action will be developed. Third, the features of the feeding vibration signal that are important to the detection will be characterized. Fourth, the kind of plant receptor likely to be detecting the feeding vibrations will be identified using mechanoreceptor mutants. This knowledge will provide targets for breeders to enhance plant resistance to insect pests.

This project will train students and postdoctoral scholars for careers in science and communication with the public. It will also train teachers to incorporate more science into their classrooms. The world of plant-borne vibrations featured in this proposal is highly appealing to children and the public at large. By providing acoustic ecology kits and training to teachers, additional children will experience the excitement and rewards of science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants receive vibrational information from their environment in much the same way that animals do, although without specialized organs like ears. It’s been known for some time that plants can respond to single tones or music, but no one knew why they would evolve this ability since these kinds of vibrations don’t occur in their natural environment. Our work has shown that ecologically relevant vibrations can be detected by plants and cause an ecologically relevant response. The ability to ‘play back’ these vibrations to recreate leaf movements with high fidelity in the absence of other signals has led to our discovery that the leaf vibrations caused by chewing caterpillars provide an early and reliable herbivory cue in Arabidopsis thaliana. The plant senses differences among vibrations caused by caterpillar feeding and other vibrations in their environment indicating that their ’sense of hearing’ is selective. We have demonstrated that caterpillar feeding vibrations trigger most of the same defense pathways against pest insects as insect feeding itself does. Feeding vibrations activate a major wound signaling pathway and cause changes in the release of airborne volatiles. They induce similar levels of defense when produced by two different species of caterpillar. The response to these vibrations depends, in part, on mechanoreceptors in the leaves. Feeding vibrations also trigger higher levels of nicotine, a chemical defense in the distantly related tobacco plant. Finally, in a survey of variation across multiple insect and plant families, we have shown that feeding vibrations of immature stages of butterflies and wasps  provide a conspicuous and consistent acoustic target for plant detection of herbivores. In addition, vibrational signals travel faster through the plant than any other known signal. Overall, this project has provided some fundamental understanding of this previously misunderstood sensory ability of plants which represents new avenues to explore for pest monitoring and control in agriculture. 

This project provided training for many STEM students: 17 undergraduate students, 7 graduate students, and 1 postdoctoral scholar. In addition, the project initiated a website for information on the vibrational world of plants and how to measure it. Lastly, 5 Latin American scientists were mentored in the use of techniques developed through this proposal.

The results of this work have been disseminated widely through 9 publications, 31 invited talks to scientific and public audiences, 23 posters at scientific conferences, and 36 media placements. The public's fascination with what plants can do provides wonderful opportunities to learn about the nature of science and the thrill of discovery, which make them better informed citizens and more likely to enter the STEM educational pipeline.
